feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued June 14 at 1:45AM AKDT until June 15 at 4:00AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 AM AKDT THURSDAY... * WHAT...High Surf expected. Strong southwesterly winds with gusts to 40 mph will create heavy wave action and will push the water levels 2 to 3 feet above the normal high tide line. * WHERE...Southern Seward Peninsula Coast.

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued June 14 at 1:45AM AKDT until June 15 at 4:00AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 AM AKDT THURSDAY... * WHAT...High Surf expected. Strong southwesterly winds with gusts to 50 mph will create heavy wave action and will push the water levels 2 to 3 feet above the normal high tide line. * WHERE...Bering Strait Coast.
entry.cap:areaDesc: St Lawrence Island and Bering Strait Coast

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 13 at 1:46PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...High Water Levels Expected This Week... Heavy rain is occuring over the northeast Brooks Range east of the Dalton Highway. Rainfall totals from 1 to 1.5 inches are possible between Monday evening and Wednesday. Runoff from this rainfall and melting of the remaining snowpack will cause rivers draining the northeast Brooks Range to rise to bankfull levels in
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Beaufort Sea Coast; Northeastern Brooks Range

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 13 at 1:40PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...High Water On The Koyukuk River This Week... Runoff from heavy rain in the Brooks Range late last week is moving down the Koyukuk River. The crest of high water is expected to reach Huslia from Wednesday into Thursday. This high water will cause erosion of the Koyukuk River bank at Huslia. Residents should prepare for significant erosion of the riverbank and high
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lower Koyukuk and Middle Yukon Valleys

entry.summary: ...A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of southern Chambers County through 515 AM CDT... At 449 AM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm over Lafayette, moving east at 35 mph. HAZARD...Winds in excess of 40 mph and half inch hail. SOURCE...Radar indicated.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued June 14 at 2:34AM CDT until June 14 at 5:15AM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: .Multiple rounds of showers and thunderstorms are forecast through Thursday evening, mainly for areas along and south of Interstate 20. Thunderstorm activity will produce locally heavy rainfall, with the potential for repeated heavy rains over the same areas. As a result, 2 to 5 inches of rain is possible through Thursday evening, with locally higher amounts possible.

entry.summary: ...CRITICAL FIRE CONDITIONS EXPECTED THURSDAY FOR SOUTHWEST NEW MEXICO AND FAR WEST TEXAS... .Winds will increase on Thursday afternoon with an upper level system across the far Southwest. entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued June 14 at 5:16AM EDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...LOCALLY DENSE FOG FOR THE MORNING COMMUTE... Some locally dense fog has formed in the Hudson River Valley, Glens Falls area, Taconics and western New England at day break. Visibilities are at a half mile or less for some locations especially near the major river valleys. Motorists should be ready for sudden changes in visibility, drive

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued June 13 at 8:18AM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: .Several days of heavy rainfall in western Hot Springs County has caused flows to increase on Owl Creek. Additionally, releases from Anchor Dam will be increased today to mitigate concerns in that area. Flows in Owl Creek are expected to be bankfull and higher to cause minor flooding concerns from Anchor Dam down to the Bighorn River.
